title: Systematic and Applied Microbiology
abstract: High diversity of Vibrio spp. associated with different ecological niches in a marine aquaria system and description of Vibrio aquimaris sp. nov

abstract.text: High diversity of Vibrio spp. associated with different ecological niches in a marine aquaria system and description of Vibrio aquimaris sp. nov

body_text.text: The genus Vibrio is one of the largest groups of bacteria cultured from a broad range of aquatic ecosystems worldwide including brackish to deep-sea water (reviewed in Ref. [66] ). Vibrio spp. are heterotrophic bacteria found as planktonic cells in water columns in concentrations ranging from 10 2 to 10 4 Vibrio spp. cells mL −1 and 10 1 to 10 3 colony forming units (CFU) mL −1 seawater, as calculated by qPCR and counting of CFU, respectively [27, 68] . Vibrio spp. also occur in a broad range of other ecological niches in aquatic systems. Their ability to use a wide variety of carbon and nitro-studies limited to cultivation-independent approaches or those based only on 16S rRNA gene phylogenies. For instance, combining culture-dependent and -independent methods, Thompson et al. [68] showed that a coastal bacterioplancton population of Vibrio splendidus consist of at least a thousand distinct genotypes present in extremely low concentrations in seawater. Genomic fingerprinting (genotyping), MALDI-TOF MS, and 16S rRNA genebased approaches were used by Rubio-Portillo et al. [55] to evaluate the diversity and genetic relatedness of Vibrio spp. from ecological niches including healthy and diseased coral tissues and seawater from two different locations in the Mediterranean Sea. Numerous genotypes were found in the studied ecological niches, several were shared among distant sampling locations, or present in diseased corals; however, 19 genotypes were found associated only to one of the ten analysed ecological niches.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Through phylogenetic and phenotypic analyses, it was possible to detect Vibrio spp. that trigger diseases in corals, shellfish, seahorses, fish, other animals of the aquaculture industry, and mammals including humans [2, 3, 5, 31, 73] . These species act as single etiologic agents or belong to consortia of bacteria that trigger diseases [27, 28, 55, 71, 73] . Pathogenicity of Vibrio spp. is linked to the expression of a broad set of virulence-related pathogenicity genes, which seems to be an ancestral trait within certain Vibrio clades and might be exchanged between members of the genus [8] . The temperature-regulation of virulence genes of several Vibrio spp. [28] indicated an increasing relevance of Vibrio spp. pathogenicity with respect to ocean warming as consequence of global climate change. This, combined with the ability of Vibrio spp. to colonize anthropogenic surfaces as MP, represents an increasing problematic in aquatic ecosystems that might affect the wildlife and human health [31, 80] .
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The phylogenetic assignment within the genus Vibrio is problematic and challenging due to the narrow boundaries delimiting species by phenotypic characteristics and their high 16S rRNA gene sequence similarities, which frequently leads to species misidentification. Species of certain clades, especially of the Harveyi clade, cannot be differentiated based on the 16S rRNA gene sequence phylogeny. A higher phylogenetic resolution of the genus was obtained by a core genome sequence phylogeny and MLSA based on few protein coding housekeeping genes [10, 47, 48, 59, 64, 65, 69] . Taxonomic studies based on MLSA with diverse schemes of housekeeping genes, have led to the identification of several new Vibrio species [9, 15, 22, 59] . Pascual et al. [47] correlated pairwise DNA-DNA hybridisation (DDH) values with nucleotide sequence similarity values obtained by the comparison of concatenated partial nucleotide sequences of the 16S rRNA gene and six selected protein coding genes, recA, pyrH, rpoD, gyrB, rctB, and toxR to define a MLSA-based nucleotide sequence similarity cut-off value, which indicates species designation.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: The aim of this study was to investigate the microdiversity of culturable Vibrio spp. within a single marine aquarium system. We address the hypothesis that a high Vibrio spp. diversity will be present in the studied aquarium system with a niche-specific colonisation of individual Vibrio spp. Five different ecological niches were studied in parallel, microplastic (MP), sandy sediments, detritus, and particle-free and particulate water fractions. The Vibrio spp. diversity was evaluated by phylotyping based on 16S rRNA gene and MLSA phylogenies. Likewise, the strain-level diversity (genotyping) was investigated by genetic fingerprinting. One phylotype could not be assigned at the species level. Subsequently one genome-sequenced representative of that phylotype was characterised by a polyphasic taxonomic approach and Vibrio aquimaris sp. nov. is proposed, with strain THAF100 T (=DSM 109633 T = LMG 31434 T = CIP 111709 T ) as type strain.
body_text.section: Introduction

body_text.text: Vibrio spp. isolates were cultured from a 80-L aquarium tank filled with artificial seawater (ASW) (ATI, Coral Ocean plus, Premium Quality Reef Salt, Germany) containing in mg L −1 , Ca 2+ : 410, Mg 2+ : 1,230, PO 4 3− : <0.03, and salinity of 34. Alkalinity (2.52 mmol L −1 ) was maintained by the addition of NaHCO 3 . The aquarium system had a constant water flow and a filtration system replaced 120 L water per day from one 4000 L tropical seawater system that harbour marine biota, which emulated a realistic marine environment. Water parameters were kept constant during the experiment (12 weeks). Water temperature was maintained at 26 • C using 300 W heaters and a feedback-controlled computer (Profilux 3, Aquatic Bus, GHL Advanced Technology GmbH & Co. KG, Kaiserslautern, Germany). The system was maintained with a 10:14 h light:dark photoperiod using T5 fluorescent tubes (Aquablue Special, ATI-Aquaristik, Germany) as light source. The tank was equipped with a horizontal and a vertical pump to generate currents. Coral fragments of the species Acropora muricata, Pocillopora verrucosa, Porites lutea, and Heliopora coerulea were placed randomly at the bottom of the tank. The system was acclimatized for two weeks before low-density polyethylene (LDPE)-MP (Novoplastik, Germany) and sandy sediment particles were added to the system. Both particle types were surfacesterilised for 24 h in 70% (v/v) ethanol and subsequently rinsed with filter-sterilised (0.22 m pore-size Sterivex filters) and autoclaved aquarium water collected from the tank. For detailed information regarding microplastic characteristics see Reichert et al. [52] . For MP, 2.5 mg of particles were added per 1 L water (200 mg per tank); this resulted in approximately 10% of particles floating in the water column (=0.25 mg L -1 ) and a count of 200 particles L −1 . Ninety g of sediment particles were added to the tank.
body_text.section: Experimental conditions of the aquarium system

body_text.text: After twelve weeks of incubation, MP randomly distributed in the water column and on the water surface, were collected with a sterile micropipette and sterile pipette tips. Sediments and detritus particles were collected from random areas of the bottom of the tanks with sterile glass pipettes. Samples were placed separately in sterile 2 mL tubes containing 1 mL of 0.22 m-filer sterilised and autoclaved ASW. All particles were rinsed with sterile ASW to remove loosely attached bacteria and transferred into 1 mL autoclaved 0.9 % (w/v) sodium chloride (NaCl) solution, and mechanically treated by vortexing to detach bacterial cells. Waterassociated bacteria were collected from 100 mL of aquarium water from the water column (20 cm depth from the surface). Particleassociated bacteria (PA) were collected from 100 mL aquarium water on a sterile 5 m Minisart syringe filter (Sartorius) using a 60 mL syringe. Bacteria were rewashed from the filter using 20 mL 0.22 m filter-sterilized and autoclaved ASW. Free-living planktonic bacteria (FL) were cultured from the flow-through of the 5 m Minisart filter.
body_text.section: Sample collection

body_text.text: Abundant particle-and water-associated heterotrophic bacteria, including Vibrio spp., were cultured from cell suspensions obtained from particles and water fractions. Cell suspensions were serially diluted (up to 10 −6 ) in 0.9% autoclaved NaCl and 100 L per dilution were plated on MA. In addition, washed particles were placed directly on MA. All plates were incubated for 2 weeks under aerobic and dark conditions at 25 • C. Most abundant and morphological different colonies were picked and purified using several transfer steps of single colonies on MA. For long-term preservation, two loops of fresh bacterial biomass were suspended in 1.4 mL ubottom push cap tubes (Micronic, Netherlands) with 500 L Gibco newborn calf serum (NBCS, ThermoFisher Scientific) and stored at −20 and −80 • C. In parallel, a cell lysate from one loop of bacterial biomass suspended in 500 L molecular grade water (Roth) was generated by three freeze-thaw cycles (−20 • C to 100 • C) by 1.5 min incubation in a heating block. Cell-lysates were used for molecular characterisation.
body_text.section: Isolation of Vibrio spp

body_text.text: Genomic fingerprinting patterns of Vibrio spp. isolates were generated by two rep-PCRs, BOX-and (GTG) 5 -PCR, according to Bartz et al. [4] . Genotypes were defined based on combined fingerprint data of BOX-and (GTG) 5 -PCRs. Genomic fingerprinting patterns were analysed in GelCompar II (Applied Maths) with the Pearson's correlation coefficient for comparison of the fingerprinting patterns and the unweighted pair group method with arithmetic mean (UPGMA) for clustering. Isolates with identical patterns most likely represent clones of the same strain were assigned to a genotype.
body_text.section: Genomic fingerprinting of Vibrio spp. isolates (genotyping)

body_text.text: Amplification of the 16S rRNA gene and housekeeping genes of Vibrio spp. isolates All Vibrio spp. with different genotypes and few of the same genotypes (in total 43 isolates), were selected for phylotyping based on partial 16S rRNA gene sequences and MLSA, respectively. PCRamplification and sequencing of the 16S rRNA gene was performed according to Bartz et al. [4] . Partial gyrB, pyrH, rctB, recA, and rpoD genes were amplified and sequenced with primers used by Pascual et al. [47] . PCR reactions were performed in a total volume of 25 L including 1 x buffer, 200 M of each dNTP, 0.5 M (each) of respective forward and reverse primers, 0.02 U Dream Taq DNA polymerase (all chemicals except primers from Fermentas/Thermo Scientific). The cycle conditions were: 95 • C for 3 min followed by 30 cycles of 95 • C for 30 s, 55 • C for 1 min 15 s, and 72 • C for 1 min15 s, and a final step at 72 • C for 7 min. All PCR products were controlled by 1 % (w/v) agarose gel electrophoresis using ethidium bromide for DNA staining, and purified and sequenced by LGC Genomics (Berlin, Germany). All sequences were corrected manually based on the electropherograms in MEGA 7 (https://www.megasoftware. net/; [33] ).
body_text.section: Genomic fingerprinting of Vibrio spp. isolates (genotyping)

body_text.text: Phylogenetic analyses based on 16S rRNA gene sequences were performed in ARB [41] . Partial 16S rRNA gene sequences were aligned with SINA version 1.2.11 (https://www.arb-silva.de/ aligner; [50] ) against the ARB seed alignment. Aligned sequences were imported into the "All-Species Living TreeProject (LTP; [78] ) ARB database release LTPs132 (June 2017). Sequences were first imported into the database tree using the Parsimony Quick at marked option. The alignment of all Vibrionaceae including the isolates was checked manually and corrected if required. A maximum-likelihood (ML) tree was constructed using RAxML 7.7.2 with GTR-GAMMA as evolutionary model and rapid bootstrap analysis (100 replications). The clustering of the isolates obtained in the ML tree was compared by the clustering obtained in a Neighbour-Joining (NJ) tree calculated with ARB NJ tool using the Jukes-Cantor distance correction as evolutionary model and 100 replications for bootstrap analysis. The Jukes-Cantor distance correction accounts for multiple base changes and assumes equal base frequencies. It is recommended for medium sized sequences (300-1000/2000 sequence length) (http://help.arb-home.de/dist. html). Pairwise 16S rRNA gene sequence similarities were determined with the ARB NJ tool without using an evolutionary model.
body_text.section: Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequences

body_text.text: Partial nucleotide sequences of the protein coding genes applied for MLSA were translated into amino acid sequences and aligned by ClustalW [67] using MEGA 7. Full-length reference genes obtained from type strains of different Vibrio species, were retrieved from a Vibrionaceae-specific EDGAR database (https://edgar.computational.bio.uni-giessen.de) [6] and used to align sequences according to the correct open reading frames (ORF). Internal gene fragments of the given nucleotide lengths, gyrB (792 bp), pyrH (480 bp), recA (681 bp), rpoD (777 bp), and rctB (645 bp), were concatenated in the given order. Only type strains with public genome sequences containing sequences of all studied genes were included in the analysis. Finally, type strains of 70 Vibrio species, four Grimontia species, and E. coli and a Shigella species (as out group), were included. Phylogenetic trees were constructed with the ML method using the General Time Reversible (GTR) model, with a discrete Gamma-distribution (+ G) with 5 rate categories and assuming that a curtain fraction of sides are evolutionary invariable (+ I) for nucleotide sequences and the Jones-Thornton-Taylor model (JTT; [24] ) + G + I for amino acid sequences. All codon positions were considered and positions containing gaps and missing data were eliminated. In addition, for all single and concatenated genes, trees were constructed with the NJ method [58] using the Kimura-2-parameter model [29] for nucleotide sequences and the JTT matrix-based method for amino acid sequences to compare the phylogenetic relationships based on single genes and to improve the phylogenetic resolution obtained by the ML calculations for the concatenated sequences. Bootstrap tests including 100 replications were used for all calculations. Pairwise sequence similarities of concatenated nucleotide and amino acid gene sequences were calculated in MEGA 7 by the determination of p-distances without using an evolutionary model. All accession number of the gene sequences generated in this study are listed in the Supplementary Table S1 .
body_text.section: MLSA based phylogenetic identification

body_text.text: Seriation analyses were performed in PAST3 (https://folk.uio. no/ohammer/past/). Analyses were based on an absence-presence (0/1) matrix using the algorithm described by Brower and Kile [7] . The analyses were used to illustrate the presence of different phylotypes and genotypes in the different ecological niches.
body_text.section: Seriation analysis

body_text.text: High molecular genomic DNA (gDNA) for genome sequencing was isolated using the NucleoSpin Microbial DNA kit (Macherey-Nagel, Germany) according to the manufacturer's instructions, but reducing the elution volume to 50 L. From the isolated gDNA, two sequencing libraries were prepared, one for sequencing on the MiSeq platform (Illumina Inc, NL) and one for sequencing on the GridION platform [Oxford Nanopore Technologies (ONT), UK]. The former was constructed using the TruSeq DNA PCR-free Library Kit (Illumina Inc, The Netherlands) and was run in a 2 × 300 nt run using a 600 cycle MiSeq Reagent Kit v3 (Illumina Inc, The Netherlands). For ONT sequencing, the Ligation Sequencing Kit SQK-LSK109 in combination was used to prepare the libraries, which was in turn run on a R9.4.1 flow cell. Base calling of the raw ONT data was performed with guppy v3.1.5 [77] . For assembly, three assemblers were utilized: The canu assembler v1.8 [32] was used to assemble the ONT data, the resulting assembled contigs were subsequently polished using the Illumina data, and the pilon polisher v1.22 [74] for a total of 10 rounds. For the first 5 rounds, bwa mem [37] was used as a mapper, for the final 5 cycles, bowtie2 [36] was applied. In addition, the Illumina data were assembled using newbler v2.8 [42] and both data sets were assembled using unicycler [76] . All assemblies were compared with each other and checked for synteny using r2cat [23] . If no divergence was found, the unicycler assembly was used for further analyses. In case of inconsistencies, all three assemblies were combined and manually curated using consed [18] . Annotation of the finished genomes was performed using prokka v1.11 [62] .
body_text.section: Complete genome sequence analysis of strain THAF100 T

body_text.text: Genome based phylogeny of Vibrio sp. isolate THAF100 T Genome-sequence based analyses of isolate THAF100 T was performed in EGDAR [6] . A core genome-based phylogenetic tree was calculated with the NJ method at the amino acid sequence level using the FastTree software (http://www.microbesonline.org/ fasttree/) to generate an approximately-maximum-likelihood phylogenetic tree [49] . The Shimodaira-Hasegawa test [63] was used to calculate local support values supporting the clustering in the tree. A total of 733 genes were considered with 757,751 amino acidresidues per genome. Strain THAF100 T , Vibrio spp. type strains, as well as a pathogenic strain of V. coralliilyticus, were included in the analysis. The type strain of Photobacterium phosphoreum was used as outgroup. Average nucleotide identity (ANI) values were calculated for strain THAF100 T and next related type strains using a method based on a BLASTN comparison of the genome sequences as described by Goris et al. [19] . A Venn diagram was generated to show numbers of shared 100 % identical paralogous genes. EDGAR assigned one to one orthologs, each gene got the best hit available as ortholog. Non identical paralogs formed their own ortholog set if there were similar paralogs in other genomes. When no similar paralogs were found, they ended up in the singleton set. A circular plot comparing strain THAF100 T and next related (type) strains was calculated in EDGAR. A selection of pathogenicity-and attachmentrelated genes were highlighted in the circular plot graph. PHASTER was used for phage detection [1] .
body_text.section: Complete genome sequence analysis of strain THAF100 T

body_text.text: Phenotypic characteristics of V-2 isolates and V. coralliilyticus LMG 20984 T were determined with standard biochemical and physiological tests including the API ZYM, API 50 CH [using CHBE medium supplemented with 3 % (w/v) aquarium salts], API 20 NE, and API 20 E test strips (Biomérieux), and a physiological test panel according to Kämpfer et al. [26] . In addition, growth on different media and temperature as well as pH and NaCl-dependent growth was tested. All analyses were performed according to Schellenberg et al. [60] . For fatty acid analyses, biomass of all V-2 isolates was cultured on MA at 28 • C for 2 days instead of TSA as normally done for Vibrio spp., since V-2 isolates did not grow on TSA even when it was supplemented with salt. Fatty acid extraction and analysis was performed according to Kämpfer and Kroppenstedt [25] , by the separation of fatty acids with a 5898A gas chromatograph (Hewlett Packard). The Sherlock Microbial Identification System (MIDI) version 2.1 (TSBA version 4.1) was used for identification from automatically integrated peaks.
body_text.section: Phenotypic characterization of V-2 isolates

body_text.text: High diversity of Vibrio spp. phylotypes were detected in the aquaria system A total of 53 Vibrio spp. isolates were cultured from the different ecological niches in the studied marine aquarium: six isolates from MP, five from sediments, 12 from detritus, and 30 from the surrounding aquarium water ( Table 1) . Water isolates were either cultured from the particulate-water fraction (5 isolates), from the particle-free water fraction (15 isolates), or from non-pre-treated aquarium water (10 isolates). Phylogenetic assignment based on partial 16S rRNA gene sequences placed the isolates into 5 phylogenetic groups within the genus Vibrio. Four out of the five groups formed distinct clusters in the ML tree calculated based on nearly full length 16S rRNA gene sequences and shared a high 16S rRNA gene sequence similarity among each other (>99%; Fig. 1 ). Those phylogenetic groups were assigned as phylotypes and named according to a respective Vibrio species if the type strain of a species was placed within the cluster. The distinctness of the phylotype clusters was supported by high bootstrap values (70-100%) in the ML tree ( Fig. 1 ) and the presence of the same cluster in a NJ tree calculated in parallel (data not shown). Three of four distinct phylotypes contained always one type strain of a described Vibrio species. Ten isolates were assigned to phylotype V-1 including MP (n = 3), sediment (3), and water (4) isolates. The V-1 isolates clustered together with the type strain of V. coralliilyticus and shared 99.4-100% pairwise 16S rRNA gene sequence similarities among each other and with the type strain (V. coralliilyticus cluster) ( Table 1 ). Eleven isolates were assigned to phylotype V-2 including water (10) and detritus (1) isolates. The isolates of V-2 shared identical 16S rRNA gene sequences and showed highest phylogenetic relationship to the type strains of the species Vibrio japonicus (98.4-98.5%) and Vibrio caribbeanicus (97.9-98.4%). Type strains of those species were not placed within the distinct V-2 cluster, but, in separate branches (V. caribbeanicus closest) next to it. In consequence, the phylotype was assigned as V. caribbeanicus-related cluster. The phylotype V-4 cluster contained seven isolates cultured from MP (3), detritus (2), and water (2) and the type strain of Vibrio fortis (V. fortis cluster). V-4 isolates shared 99.4-100% 16S rRNA gene sequence similarity among each other and with the type strain of V. fortis. Two isolates from the non-pre-treated water clustered together with type strains of V. mediterranei/" V. shilonii" and formed the V-5 (V. mediterranei/" V. shilonii") phylotype. These isolates shared 99.8 % 16S rRNA gene sequence similarity among each other and 99.6 % with the type strains of V. mediterranei/" V. shilonii". The remaining 23 Vibrio spp. isolates from sediments (2), detritus (9) , and water (12) were placed within the Harveyi clade and assigned as Harveyi clade cluster V-3 because Vibrio spp. of this clade cannot be clearly differentiated based on the 16S rRNA gene sequence phylogeny [69] . Seven of the V-3 isolates (two of sediments and five of detritus) formed a distinct sub-cluster with the type strain of Vibrio harveyi (V. harveyi V-3.1 phylotype). The isolates shared identical 16S rRNA gene sequences among each other and with the V. harveyi type strain. The remaining isolates placed into the Harveyi clade shared 98.0-100% 16S rRNA gene sequence similarities among each other and with type strains of different Vibrio species within the Harveyi clade.
body_text.section: Results and discussion

body_text.text: The MLSA phylogeny based on concatenated partial nucleotide and amino acid sequences of recA, pyrH, rpoD, gyrB, and rctB, confirmed the phylogenetic assignment of phylotypes V-1, V-2, V-3.1, V-4, and V-5 ( Fig. 2) . In addition, the remaining Harveyi clade (V-3 cluster) isolates could be grouped into two further distinct clusters and two additional phylotypes were defined. Ten of the Harveyi clade isolates (two of detritus and eight of water) formed a distinct cluster with the type strain of V. owensii (V. owensii phylotype V-3.2). The remaining six Harveyi clade isolates (two of detritus, four of water) formed a distinct sub-cluster with the type strain of V. alginolyticus (V. alginolyticus phylotype V-3.2). The distinction of the V-3.2 and V-3.3 isolates was obtained in nucleotide-and Phylotypes and number of isolates per phylotype detected in the different ecological niches in the studied system. Intra-phylotype pairwise sequence similarities based on partial 16S rRNA gene sequences and partial concatenated nucleotide and amino acid sequences of five protein coding genes are depicted. Similarity values represent ranges of pairwise sequence similarities among phylotype isolates and values given in brackets are ranges of pairwise sequence similarities of the phylotype isolates to next related type strain placed within a phylotype cluster. In addition, the similarity value to the next related type strain beside the phylotype cluster is given. MP: microplastic particles; Sed: sandy sediment particles; Det: detritus particles; FL: free-living water-associated bacteria; PA: particle-attached water-associated bacteria. (-) no type strain placed within the phylotype cluster. amino acid-based MLSA trees, calculated based on concatenated sequences of the housekeeping genes ( Fig. 2a, b ) and on nucleotide and most amino acid sequence based phylogenetic trees calculated based on individual protein-coding genes ( Supplementary  Fig. S1−5) . Only in the amino acid based trees of recA (Supplementary Fig. 1b ) and pyrH ( Supplementary Fig. 2b ) the two clusters could not be differentiated.
body_text.section: Higher phylogenetic resolution of Vibrio spp. isolates by MLSA-based phylogeny

body_text.text: The isolates of six out of seven of the defined phylotypes (all except V-2) formed distinct clusters including always a type strains of the phylotype naming species as shown in the MLSA trees calculated with the ML method ( Fig. 2a, b) . Stability of the clusters was supported by high bootstrap values (≥70%) and confirmed by phylogenetic trees calculated with the NJ method (data not shown). Isolates and the respective type strains of individual phylotypes shared always high nucleotide (>98%) and mostly identical amino acid sequence (99.0-100%) among each other when the concatenated sequences of the five housekeeping genes were compared (Table 1) . Vibrio spp. isolates and type strains placed within the same clusters shared sequence similarities of concatenated nucleotide sequences that were always in the range of the Supplementary Table S1 . Individual gene trees calculated based on nucleotide and amino acid sequences are depicted in Supplementary Fig. S1-5 .
body_text.section: Higher phylogenetic resolution of Vibrio spp. isolates by MLSA-based phylogeny

body_text.text: intra-species similarities and above the MLSA-based cut-off values proposed by Pascual et al. [47] after a detailed study correlating DDH and MLSA-based similarity values. Here however, in contrast to Pascual et al. [47] , a different set of genes was considered: recA, pyrH, rpoD, gyrB, and rctB, instead of rpoD, rctB, and toxR. The toxR gene was excluded form analyses because it could not be amplified from all isolates.
body_text.section: Higher phylogenetic resolution of Vibrio spp. isolates by MLSA-based phylogeny

body_text.text: The V. caribbeanicus-related phylotype V-2 was, based on MLSA, distinct to all current Vibrio species. In the nucleotide sequencebased MLSA tree, the phylotype was placed in a distinct branch next to the type strain of V. caribbeanicus (Fig. 2a) . In the amino acid-based tree the V-2 cluster was placed next to the V. coralliilyticus V-1 cluster but without high bootstrap support (Fig. 2b) . Vibrio japonicus was not included in the five gene-based MLSA approach, because no genome sequence and only recA, pyrH, and gyrB gene sequences were available for the type strain [15] . Additional analyses based only on those three genes showed no clustering of the V. japonicus type strain with V-2 isolates, neither at the nucleotide nor at the amino acid sequence level ( Supplementary Fig. S1-S3 ). The V-2 isolates shared nearly (99.9-100%) identical nucleotide sequences and identical amino acid sequences indicating the assignment of all isolates to the same species.
body_text.section: Higher phylogenetic resolution of Vibrio spp. isolates by MLSA-based phylogeny

body_text.text: Seriation analysis showed the presence and absence of the seven detected phylotypes in the different ecological niches. The water contained, with six out of seven phylotypes, the highest diversity of Vibrio spp. (Fig. 3) . In contrast, only two Vibrio phylotypes were isolated from MP and sediment particles. Representatives of the V. coralliilyticus phylotype (V-1) were isolated from both surfaces, while representatives of the V. fortis phylotype (V-4) only from MP and the V. harveyi phylotype (V-3.1) only from sediment particles. These three phylotypes were also isolated from detritus, water, or both.
body_text.section: Different distribution of Vibrio spp. phylotypes among different ecological niches

body_text.text: In several studies, V. coralliilyticus, V. harveyi, V. owensii, V. alginolyticus, V. fortis, and V. mediterranei, all known pathogens, have been isolated mainly from seawater, but also associated to healthy or diseased animals [10, 27, 55, 56] . Our findings are in agreement with these observations since all phylotypes isolated from the aquaria system, except V. harveyi (V-3.1) were isolated from water samples. Only few reports have indicated the presence of Vibrio spp. on plastic particles using a high-resolution cultivation-dependent approach. So far, V. coralliilyticus, V. alginolyticus, and V. harveyi were detected on plastic particles [16, 31, 61] . Here, the presence of V. fortis associated to MP was reported for the first time. These results supports the hypothesis that MP acts as a vector of potential pathogens as discussed previously, although this is still a topic contrarily debated [31, 45, 80] .
body_text.section: Different distribution of Vibrio spp. phylotypes among different ecological niches

body_text.text: Some phylotypes displayed habitat preferences, tending to be more abundant either in water (V-2, V-3.2, V-3.3, and V-5) or associated to surfaces (V-1, V-3.1, and V-4). It is known that different algae might be accumulated on biotic and abiotic surfaces that can lead to close associations with bacteria through the production of algal exudates and other dissolved organic carbon substrates that stimulate fast-growing bacteria such as Vibrio spp. [14, 44] . The differential capacity to assimilate algal-derived substances might have contributed to the partitioning of individual Vibrio spp. phylotypes in the different ecological niches of the aquarium system. Furthermore, particular genetic traits may be selectively present in Vibrio spp. in the aquarium system, which provide advantages to certain genotypes for surface attachment, colonization, and biofilm formation.
body_text.section: Different distribution of Vibrio spp. phylotypes among different ecological niches

body_text.text: Genotypic differentiation of Vibrio spp. isolates and niche-specific genotype abundance UPGMA clustering based on genomic fingerprint patterns (compared with the Pearson correlation coefficient) grouped the Vibrio spp. isolates into clusters according to the phylotype clustering (Fig. 4) . In total, isolates were differentiated into 27 genotypes (strain-level differentiation) and between two to six different genotypes were obtained for each phylotype. The lowest intraphylotype diversity was obtained for isolates of V-2, all except one isolate (THAF213), shared the same fingerprint patterns (Fig. 4) . The isolate THAF213 showed an identical BOX-PCR pattern with the other V-2 isolates and only a minor difference in the (GTG) 5 -PCR pattern (Fig. 4) . Seriation analysis based on an absence-presence (0/1) matrix of the individual genotypes per ecological niches, showed that the highest genotype diversity was recovered from detritus and water samples. Only few genotypes were cultured from MP and sediment particle (Fig. 5) . Almost all MP-derived isolates represented different genotypes, only two isolates shared the same genotype (V-4-1), and two genotypes were MP-specific (V-1-1 and V-1-4). In a similar manner, the five sediment-derived isolates represented four genotypes, from which two were sedimentspecific. Five out of ten and 11 out of 16 genotypes cultured from detritus and water were only detected from the respective ecological niche. The genotyping illustrated that the diversity of Vibrio spp. within the studied aquarium system was much higher than indicated by the 16S rRNA gene and MLSA approaches. For a statistical estimation of a niche specificity the number of studied isolates was unfortunately still too low.
body_text.section: Different distribution of Vibrio spp. phylotypes among different ecological niches

body_text.text: In this study, through genotyping, it was possible to observe a considerable heterogeneity at the strain level within the Vibrio phylotypes as found by Rubio-Portillo et al. [55] during the identification of genotypes of pathogenic Vibrio spp. associated with corals from different geographical locations. Factors that induce such a Vibrio spp. diversity are still unclear. Environmental pressures, competition among strains, accumulation of neutral allelic variations, and horizontal gene transfer have been discussed as causes of ecologically distinct populations with adaptive mutations that might explain genotype diversity [68] . According to Thompson et al. [68] , the genotype diversity and niche-specific differences in the aquarium system may reflect a starting point of specialization of (sub)populations to either a planktonic or surface-associated life style, especially on surfaces as MP and sandy sediments, which were added sterile to the system and selectively colonized during 12 weeks of incubation. The expression of certain phenotypes related to colonization factors could have favoured the transition of cells from a planktonic to a particle-attached lifestyle, thriving in new ecological niches, for example in the cases of MP-and sediment-associated genotypes of the V-1 and V-3.1 phylotypes (Fig. 5) . This indicates the presence of a niche-specific genotype diversity within the system.
body_text.section: Different distribution of Vibrio spp. phylotypes among different ecological niches

body_text.text: Our study provided evidence to the discussion about MP as vectors of pathogenic Vibrio spp. as V. coralliilyticus or V. fortis, which may threat animal health since MP can be ingested by corals and other marine animals [20, 52] . In order to address this hypothesis, the cultured Vibrio spp. should be used to determine the presence of pathogenicity-related genes by genomic analyses and tested in vivo to determine their virulence potential on animals.
body_text.section: Different distribution of Vibrio spp. phylotypes among different ecological niches

body_text.text: More detailed genotypic analyses were performed to confirm that phylotype V-2 represents a novel Vibrio species because neither in the 16S rRNA gene nor in the MLSA-based phylogenetic trees the phylotype clustered with any of the Vibrio species type strains ( Fig. 1 and 2 ; Supplementary Figs. 1-5 ). Due to the low genotype Cluster analysis was performed in GelCompar II version 4.5 (Applied Maths) using UPGMA clustering, based on a dissimilarity matrices generated by the Pearson correlation for the two fingerprint patterns which were subsequently merged. variability among isolates assigned to phylotype V-2, one isolate, THAF100 T , was selected for further genotypic studies. BLAST analysis based on the nearly full-length 16S rRNA gene against the EzBioCloud database [79] indicated that the closest related type strains to strain THAF100 T were those of V. japonicus (16S rRNA gene sequence similarity, 98.5 %) and V. caribbeanicus (98.4 %), followed by Vibrio sinaloensis (98.2 %) and Vibrio brasiliensis (98.1 %).
body_text.section: Genome data support the novel species status of phylotype V-2

body_text.text: A complete genome sequence was generated for strain THAF100 T . The genome had a size of 4.5 Mbp with a G + C content of 42.7 %, 4,111 assigned genes, and 3,880 of these protein-coding. The genome was structured into a chromosome of 3,138,671 bp (CP045350.1), a large plasmid (or second chromosome, see below) of a size of 1,317,907 bp (pTHAF100 a; CP045351.1), and two additional plasmids, 9,604 bp (pTHAF100 b; CP045352.1) and 4,831 bp (pTHAF100 c; CP045353.1). The plasmid assignment was performed based on plasmid typical genetic elements, e.g. plasmidtype replication system. The large plasmid pTHAF100 a represents the second chromosome which is described for other complete genome sequenced Vibrio ssp. because it also contains several housekeeping genes, typical for chromosomes and untypical for plasmids [28, 46, 64] . In literature this genetic element was also assigned as chromid or megaplasmid [21, 30] . All ribosomal RNA gene operons were located on the main chromosome (CP045350.1).
body_text.section: Genome data support the novel species status of phylotype V-2

body_text.text: The strain contained nine rRNA operons including three of the nine 16S rRNA gene sequences that showed 1-3 nucleotide differences (Supplementary Table 2 ) as reported for several other bacteria [40] . The genome structure and the number of ribosomal operons were similar to those obtained for other Vibrio spp. genomes [28, 57, 64] .
body_text.section: Genome data support the novel species status of phylotype V-2

body_text.text: The phylogenetic placement of strain THAF100 T (as representative of the V-2 phylotype) into the genus Vibrio was confirmed based on the core genome phylogenetic tree calculated at the amino acid sequence level. The tree confirmed the close phylogenetic relationship of strain THAF100 T to the type strain of V. coralliilyticus (Fig. 6) . The comparison of MLSA and core genome phylogenies indicates a conserved topology between the amino acid sequencebased MLSA tree and the amino acid based core-genome tree. This confirms the validity of the amino acid-based analysis of the applied MLSA scheme as a robust method to infer the phylogenetic relationship of those Vibrio species.
body_text.section: Genome data support the novel species status of phylotype V-2

body_text.text: ANI values of strain THAF100 T and the type strains of V. coralliilyticus and V. caribbeanicus (next related based on MLSA and core genome phylogeny) were low, 74.8 and 70.8%, respectively. The type strains of those two species also shared a similar low ANI value among each other (70.9%). These values are clearly below the 95-96 % ANI species cut-off values proposed previously [19, 53] . A Venn diagram depicting the numbers of 100% identical paralogous genes is shown in Supplementary Fig. S6 . The genomes of THAF100 T and type strains of V. coralliilyticus and V. caribbeanicus shared 2,453 paralogous genes but also a high number of singletons or genes just shared with one of the other strains. The genome of THAF100 T contained 917 singleton genes and shared 205 or 448 paralogous genes only with the type strains of V. caribbeanicus and V. coralliilyticus, respectively. With 287 genes, those two genomes also shared a similar amount of paralogous genes only among each other and carried 1,078 and 1,832 individual gene, respectively. The genomic subset distributions between the three genomes indicated that for chromosome I 54% of 6,795 CDS represent singletons, 28.9% belong to the core, and 17.1% were dispensable; while for chromosome II (chromid) 54.5 % of 6,663 CDS represent singletons, only 8% belong to the core, and 37.6% were dispensable ( Supplementary  Fig. S7 ).
body_text.section: Genome data support the novel species status of phylotype V-2

body_text.text: Presence of putative pathogenicity-related genes in Vibrio sp.
body_text.section: Genome data support the novel species status of phylotype V-2

body_text.text: Based on the MLSA and genome-based phylogenetic analyses, the closest related species of strain THAF100 T is the coral pathogenic species V. coralliilyticus, which suggests that the novel species may be pathogenic as well. A pangenome approach of strain THAF100 T , V. coralliilyticus ATCC BAA-450 T , V. caribbeanicus ATCC BAA-2122 T , and V. coralliilyticus OCN008 (pathogenic strains) was done to identify pathogenicity-related genes present in strain THAF100 T (Fig. 7) . Specific genetic traits linked to a potential pathogenicity of strain THAF100 T were the presence of fimbria assembly proteins (locus tags FIV01 RS01130-RS01140), decisive in motility and adhesion to eukaryotic hosts, where invasion protein regulator and the attachment invasion locus protein precursor also play a pivotal role [51] . Other traits were a permease that contribute to pathogenesis (FIV01 RS04105) [54] , components of toxin-antitoxin systems, including genes coding for toxins as RelE2 (FIV01 RS06200) or HigB-2 (FIV01 RS13385) that inhibit cell growth, and antitoxin HipB (FIV01 RS03265) that inhibits the activity of the toxin, involved in bacterial persistence during stressing conditions and antibiotic tolerance [9, 13, 75] . Quorum sensing-related genes that codify for acylprotein LuxE synthase (FIV01 RS00090), homoserine lactone efflux proteins (FIV01 RS01990), and sensory histidine kinase-like DcuS from the two-component sensor-regulator system (DcuS-DcuR) (FIV01 RS00665) that regulates gene expression [17] were addi- 6 . Core genome phylogenetic tree based on amino acid sequences constructed with the FastTree software using EDGAR [6] . Multiple alignments of 733 genes were generated using MUSCLE for 81 genomes. In total, 757,751 amino acid residues per genome were included in the analysis. The genome sequence of Photobacterium phosphoreum ATCC 11040 T was used as outgroup. Numbers at nodes represent local support values generated with the Shimodaira-Hasegawa test that was calculated supporting the clustering in the tree. tionally detected only in the genome of strain THAF100 T . Quorum sensing systems regulate, among others virulence, biofilm formation, pathogenicity, motility, or adhesion [38] . All isolates assigned to the same phylotype as THAF100 T (V-2) were cultivated from the water column except for one obtained from detritus. The studied MP and sediment surfaces seemed not to be the ecological niche of the novel species, but neither attachment nor biofilm formation activity were proved yet for the species yet. Transposable genetic Fig. 7 . Circular plot generated in the EDGAR platform [6] depicting pathogenicity-related genes present only in the genome of the strain THAF100 T or shared with the strains V. coralliilyticus ATCC BAA-450 T , V. caribbeanicus ATCC BAA-2122 T , and V. coralliilyticus OCN008 (*). The locus tags of the genes of strain THAF100 T are shown in brackets. elements related to the transposon Tn7 (FIV01 RS02105-RS02125) as well as phage-related genes (FIV01 RS09550) represent additional differential genetic traits detected for strain THAF100 T and the reference strains. These elements play pivotal roles in genetic exchange and gene expression contributing to mutations, deletions, insertions, and adaptations [2, 66] . The presence of prophage genomes in the genome of strain THAF100 T was further evaluated through the PHASTER server [1] . No prophages were detected in the chromosome I, pTHAF100 a (chromid), and plasmid pTHAF100 c. However, one apparently complete intact prophage genome was located on plasmid pTHAF100 b which was related to the plasmidlike phage VP882, already characterised from a pandemic V. parahaemolyticus strain [35] . The phage genome encodes 59 proteins and covered almost the entirety of the plasmid (39.4 Kb from the 39.6 Kb of the plasmid). This indicates that this is a plasmidlike phage and not a hybrid of a phage and plasmid. It maintained like a plasmid since it was not integrate into the host chromosome. Interestingly, the phage proteome contain transcriptional regulators of quorum sensing that might regulate physiological of virulence-related traits in the host [35] .
body_text.section: THAF100 T

body_text.text: The coral pathogens V. coralliilyticus strains ATCC BAA-450 T and OCN008 contain potential virulence-associated genes which are regulated by water temperature, which may explain disease outbreaks and bleaching episodes in warm waters [28, 71, 73] . Strain THAF100 T and V. caribbeanicus ATCC BAA-2122 T shared some of those genes with those pathogenic strains, although the latter one is reported as non-pathogenic [22] . For instance a cluster of flagellar biosynthesis proteins (FIV01 RS10605-RS10725) that influence Table 2 Phenotypic characteristics differentiating V-2 isolates (n = 9) including THAF100 T , further phylotype V-2 isolates, from the closely related type strains of the genus Vibrio. THAF100 T and 7 further isolate with identical genomic fingerprint patterns including THAF79, THAF126, THAF136, THAF157, THAF174, THAF175, and THAF178; 2, strain THAF213; 3, V. coralliilyticus LMG 20984 T ; 4, V. caribbeanicus N384 T ; 5, V. japonicus JCM 31412 T . Strains 1, 2, and 3 were studied in parallel under the same cultivation conditions. All the strains were rod-shaped, motile, and positive for the activity of oxidase and DNase. Positive for alkaline phosphatase, and leucine arylamidase, but negative for aesculin hydrolysis, cystine arylamidase, ␣-chymotrypsin, ␤-galactosidase, ␣-glucosidase, ␤-glucosidase, ␣-mannosidase, ␣-fucosidase (API ZYM), and negative for ornithine decarboxylase (API 20E). All strains utilize d-fructose and (␣-) d-glucose (physiological test panel according to Kämpfer et al. [26] ). +, positive; -, negative; NA, not available. Data and DNA G + C content values for strains 3 (in brackets), 4, and 5 were taken from Ben-Haim et al. [5] , Hoffmann et al. [22] , and Doi et al. [15] , respectively. 1 API 20NE. 2 API 20E. 3 API ZYM. 4 API 50CH. 5 Physiological test panel according to Kämpfer et al. [26] . 6 Only determined for strain THAF100 T .
body_text.section: THAF100 T

body_text.text: pathogenicity through motility or Type II secretion system proteins (FIV01 RS00515-RS00570), which translocate virulence factors, toxins, and enzymes across the outer membrane [11] . The quorum sensing receptors LuxR and LuxQ (FIV01 RS12310, FIV01 RS05710), responsible for the induction and repression of several pathogenicity, as well as chemotaxis proteins (FIV01 RS09775) that play important roles in initial steps of infection, mainly in the detection of hosts [39, 70] , were also detected. Likewise, a ABC transporter permease (FIV01 RS06260) involved in bacterial resistance [43] was also detected in all the compared genomes. Additional exclusive and shared genes found in the genome of strain THAF100 T are depicted in Fig. 7 .
body_text.section: THAF100 T

body_text.text: As suggested by Rubio-Portillo et al. [55] , the virulence level vary even within members of the same phylotype. It is therefore not clear if the potential pathogenicity is just a sign of the investigated strain or a general trait of the proposed species. Moreover, the presence of pathogenicity-related genes just indicated virulence but did not prove it. Further isolates were cultured from water and detritus (potential second strain) of the same marine aquaria system as the type strain Information related to the Nagoya Protocol Country of origin, Germany, party of Nagoya as of 20/07/2016. Locality if sampling within the country Justus-Liebig University Giessen, Animal Facility, "Ocean 2100" CEMarin aquarium system. No permits required. Designation of the Type Strain THAF100 T Strain Collection Numbers DSM 109633 T = LMG 31434 T = CIP 111709 T
body_text.section: THAF100 T

body_text.text: The V-2 isolates showed typical phenotypic properties that define the genus Vibrio: motile, rod-shaped, and Gram-negative staining cells, positive for cytochrome C oxidase and catalase activity. The isolates grew under aerobic and anaerobic conditions. Phenotypic traits of the V-2 isolates were compared with those published for the type strains of V. coralliilyticus, V. caribbeanicus, and V. japonicus [5, 22, 15] (Table 2) . Vibrio coralliilyticus LMG 20984 T was thereby analysed in parallel with the V-2 isolates in the same laboratory. Several differentiating phenotypic fea-tures were found for the V-2 isolates and the reference type strains, for instance, differences in growth in the salt-tolerance test, nitrate reduction, indole production, differential utilisation of carbon sources, enzymatic activities, fermentation, and assimilation of sugars ( Table 2 ). The phenotypically characterized V-2 isolates included THAF100 T , seven further isolates with identical fingerprint patterns, and the genotypically different isolate, strain THAF213, showed only slight variations among each other (7 traits), while 31 traits were determined which differentiated the V2-isolates to at least one of the other type strains ( Table 3) . The comparison of the physiological properties of the V2-isolates and V. coralliilyticus LMG 20984 T was extended by the application of a physiological test panel including acid production from and assimilation of carbon sources, as well as enzymatic activity, designed by Kämpfer et al. [26] . The comparative analysis gave 15 traits which differentiated the V2-isolates from V. coralliilyticus LMG 20984 T . Again, some traits (seven at all) were determined that showed variation among the V2-isolates (Supplementary Table S3 ). The predominant cellular fatty acid patterns of strain THAF100 T and the other V-2 isolates (including THAF213) were typical for the genus Vibrio, which includes C 12:0 , C 14:0 , C 16:0 , summed feature 3 (C 16:1 7c and/or C16:1 6c), C 18:1 7c, and/or C 18:1 6c [34] . Variation in minor fatty acids were obtained among the tested V-2 isolates and to type strains of next related species (Supplementary  Table S4 ).
body_text.section: Phenotypic and chemotaxonomic characterisation of V-2 isolates

body_text.text: Results obtained from the polyphasic characterisation, including 16S rRNA gene-and MLSA based phylogenies, genome-based analyses, genotyping, phenotypic tests, and chemotaxonomy, demonstrated that the V-2 isolates represent a novel species of the genus Vibrio, clearly differentiable from its closest related species based on phenotypic and genetic traits. Strain THAF100 T was selected as type strain. Nine other isolates showed identical genomic fingerprint pattern to THAF100 T . One isolate THAF213 represented a potential second strain (showing slight variations in the (GTG) 5 -PCR fingerprint pattern). All V-2 isolates shared common phylogenetic, phenotypic, and chemotaxonomic traits. The name Vibrio aquimaris is proposed with THAF100 T (=DSM 109633 T = LMG 31434 T = CIP 111709 T ) as the type strain. The protologue description of the species is given in Table 3 .
body_text.section: Phenotypic and chemotaxonomic characterisation of V-2 isolates

FIGREF0.text: Maximum-likelihood tree showing the phylogenetic placement of the isolated Vibrio spp. based on the nearly full-length 16S rRNA gene sequences. The tree was calculated in ARB using RAxML, GTR-GAMMA, and rapid bootstrap analysis (100 resamplings). Bootstrap values (> %) are given at the branch nodes. The GenBank accession numbers are given in parentheses. The type strains of Escherichia coli and Shigella dysenteriae were used as out-group. Bar, number of substitutions per nucleotide positions.

FIGREF1.text: Phylogenetic placement of the Vibrio spp. isolates within the genus Vibrio based on MLSA. Trees are calculated based on concatenated partial sequences of recA, pyrH, rpoD, gyrB, and rctB at nucleotide (a) and amino acid (b) levels using the ML algorithm and the evolutionary models GTR (nucleotide sequences) and JTT (amino acid sequences) in MEGA7. Bootstrap values (>70%) based on 100 resamplings are shown at branch nodes. Photobacterium phosphoreum ATCC 11040 T was used as out-group. The trees based on 3357 nucleotide and 1120 amino acid sequence positions. Bars, number of substitutions per nucleotide or amino acid sequence positions. GenBank accession numbers of gene sequences of the isolates are listed in the

FIGREF2.text: Seriation analysis based on an absence-presence (0/1) matrix illustrating the presence of Vibrio sp. phylotypes in the different ecological niches of the aquaria system.

FIGREF3.text: Genotyping of Vibrio spp. isolates based on fingerprint patterns obtained by genomic fingerprinting using primers targeting BOX and (GTG)5 repetitive elements.

FIGREF4.text: Seriation analysis based on an absence-presence (0/1) matrix illustrating the presence of Vibrio sp. genotypes in the in the different ecological niches of the aquaria system.

FIGREF5.text: Fig. 6. Core genome phylogenetic tree based on amino acid sequences constructed with the FastTree software using EDGAR [6]. Multiple alignments of 733 genes were generated using MUSCLE for 81 genomes. In total, 757,751 amino acid residues per genome were included in the analysis. The genome sequence of Photobacterium phosphoreum ATCC 11040 T was used as outgroup. Numbers at nodes represent local support values generated with the Shimodaira-Hasegawa test that was calculated supporting the clustering in the tree.

FIGREF7.text: Cells are rod-shaped, 2.5 (±0.4) m length × 0.8 (±0.1) m width, Gram-stain negative, motile, aerobic, and facultative anaerobic. Colonies on MA after 3 days of incubation are ∼ 3 mm in diameter, beige, circular, convex, with entire borders. Best growth occurs on MA, also on CASO, glycine/arginine, LB, PYE, R2A [all supplemented with 3 % (w/v) NaCl], PYES supplemented with 3 % (w/v) aquarium salts, and Columbia agar. The species is mesophilic with growth between 8 and 37 • C (optimum 28 • C) and moderate halophilic with growth in the presence of 1.0−11.0 % NaCl (optimum 2.0−9.0 %). It has a wide pH range of growth, pH 4.5 to pH 10.0 (optimum pH 4.5−7.0). Positive for cytochrome oxidase and catalase activity, negative for citrate utilization, nitrate reduction, production of indole, hydrogen sulphide, and acetoin(Voges-Proskauer). Tyrosine, casein, gelatine, hypoxanthine (weakly), DNA, Tween 40, 60, and 80 are hydrolysed, but adenine, aesculin, starch, xanthin, xylan, cellulose, and blood are not. Positive for the activity of alkaline phosphatase, leucine arylamidase, acid phosphatase, naphthol-AS-BI-phosphohydrolase, and N-acetyl-␤-glucosaminidase, but negative for the activity of cystine arylamidase, ␣-chymotrypsin, ␣-galactosidase, ␤-galactosidase, ␤-glucuronidase, ␣-glucosidase, ␤-glucosidase, ␣-mannosidase, and ␣-fucosidase, and variable for the activity of lipase (C14), esterase (C4), esterase lipase (C8), valine arylamidase, and trypsin. Positive for the production of acid from d-mannose, d-fructose, d-maltose, d-sucrose, starch, glycogen, and potassium 2-ketogluconate, but negative for the production of acid from dulcitol, adonitol, 1-O-methyl-d-glucopyranosid, glycerol, erythritol, d-arabinose, l-xylose, d-adonitol, methyl-␤-d-xylopyranoside, d-galactose, d-glucose, d-sorbose, l-rhamnose, inositol, d-mannitol, d-sorbitol, methyl-␣-d-mannopyranoside, methyl-␣-d-glucopyranoside, N-acetylglucosamine, amygdalin, arbutin, salicin, d-cellobiose, d-lactose, d-melibiose, d-trehalose, inulin, d-melezitose, d-raffinose, xylitol, gentiobiose, d-turanose, d-lyxose, d-tagatose, d-fucose, l-fucose, d-arabitol, l-arabitol, potassium gluconate, and potassium 5-ketogluconate, and variable for acid production from d-glucose, l-arabinose, and d-xylose. Cells assimilate N-acetyl-d-glucosamine, d-fructose, ␣-d-glucose, d-maltose, d-mannose, fumarate, dl-lactate, l-alanine, l-aspartate, l-ornithine (hydrochloride), l-proline, and l-serine, but not d-cellobiose, d-galactose, mannitol, putrescine, cis-aconitate, trans-aconitate, adipate, 4-aminobutyrate, azelate, citrate, glutarate, dl-3-hydroxybutyrate, itaconate, mesaconate, pyruvate, suberate, ␤-alanine, l-histidine, l-leucine, l-phenylalanine, l-tryptophan, 3-hydroxybenzoate, 4-hydroxybenzoate, and dl-3-phenylacetate, and variable for sodium acetate, 2-oxoglutarate, propionate, l-malate, d-trehalose. Positive for the hydrolyse of bis-pNP-phosphate, pNP-phenyl-phosphonate, pNP-phosphoryl-choline, l-alanine-pNA, and negative for the hydrolysis of pNP-␤-d-galactopyranoside, pNP-␤-d-glucuronide, pNP-␣-d-glucopyranoside, pNP-␤-d-glucopyranoside, l-glutamate-␥-carboxy pNA pNP-␤-d-xylopyranoside, pNP-phosphate-disodium salt, l-proline-pNA, pNP-␤-d-xylopyranoside, arginine dihydrolase, urease, lysine decarboxylase, tryptophan deaminase, and ornithine decarboxylase are negative. Major fatty acids are summed feature 3 (C16:17c and/or C16:16c), C16:0, and C18:17c.
